Which I‚Äôm learning I actually suffer from. Even tho I‚Äôm a woman. Which is weird to think about...a young woman who used to buy so much into ‚Äúbeing one of the good ones‚Äù that she literally started thinking like those guys who call themselves ‚Äúalphas‚Äù

And just...I wish I could go back in time...and in the gentlest way possible....call my past self an idiot.

And I know past me would take anything critical I said of her too hard, and she‚Äôd start crying...and then current me would feel bad, and I‚Äôd want to hug past me and tell her it‚Äôll be okay. (Lol did any of that make any sense to anybody other than me?)

And then I‚Äôd rip the universe apart because I‚Äôd break the spacetime continuum. Actually, I‚Äôm pretty sure Doc from Back to the Future (what I‚Äôm trying to reference for anybody that doesn‚Äôt know that) calls it the Time-Space continuum. Oh well. 

I just looked back to check for spelling errors, and I realized I started talking about the current me/past me thing like we‚Äôre different people. Past me was still me like...last August. But like...the way I see it, I‚Äôve changed so much in such a short time...I‚Äôm a completely different person than I was less than a year ago. 

Okay, I‚Äôve spent entirely too long writing this comment. I‚Äôm going to be done now. Peace out my dude :)

replies.author: @josuemontero2675
replies.text: The first Crusade was defensive from a certain perspective, the Roman Emperor asked for military aid to the Pope. At that time the Eastern Roman empire was already hiring the services of feudal knights, and when the Seljuk Turks invaded Anatolia along with a mass migration of Turks from central Asia, it severely weakened the Eastern Roman Empire. Obviously, this is a threat because the Eastern Roman Empire was basically a buffer state and eventually the Seljuk Turks were replaced by the Ottomans who conquered the Balkans, Hungary and Austria. Smaller empires are better than one big empire if you are a kingdom. But during/after the first crusade things dissolved and political tensions arose. And that basically starts with the Crusaders thinking they were betrayed by the Eastern Roman Emperor, because he was given incorrect information that some of were defeated at a battle and thus no longer went to aid them in the battle. Any conquered territory was to be given to Eastern Roman Empire, but after that incident factions arose that established their own territories. To view the expanding Seljuks Turks as a threat and viewing it necessary to strengthen the Eastern Roman Empire is justified, but anything beyond that is not.

from what I've read, some historians suggest that he may not have been a sadist; he presented himself as one to sew fear. For an example of what I'm talking about in regards to sewing fear, after obtaining the throne of Wallachia, Vlad had a castle built for himself. This castle including a grueling prison and torture chamber specifically for the people that had his father and elder brother killed, and the torture chamber was directly underneath his bedroom. Imagine the fear that that would sew among the nobility in Wallachia.

Blacksmithing was important and technologically wasn't really that far off from anyone else. Just that there wasn't really an unified nation, though Chieftains called themselves 'Kuningas', a word for king, which is the alternate word for similar "Kuningaz" word in Latin of similar meaning, keeping rather old, almost forgotten words alive. Would've been interesting to see what it would be like without the crusades. There were even legends of one notable chieftain called 'Kirmukarmu' who hunted down christians.

It's probably exaggeration, but the reason the quote is still repeated is partly because it can give a hint of the real experience of Raymond d'Aguilers, the man who actually witnessed it and made that claim. After all, how bad must it have been that he decided to describe it this way?

replies.author: @Kingoftherednex
replies.text:
The average adult man has about 1.3 to 1.5 gallons of blood in his body.

If we assume everyone in the city was an adult, and they were all nice and hydrated despite living in the desert, so everyone's at 1.5, then five people would provide 7.5 gallons of blood--and 7.5 gallons of water is a cubic foot.

A quick check finds my knee at 50 centimeters up, barefoot.  So let's assume they were short than I am (even though I stand at 5'7", and that they too were barefoot, so their knees are 45 centimeters up--that's a foot and a half.

And let's say they were in an alley, only three feet wide, and ten feet long.  That's 30 square feet of space, so  to make it a foot and a half deep would be 45 cubic feet of blood.

That means that for that small alley to have blood up to their knees would require 225 people to be killed, AND to have every drop of blood drained out of them.

Some accounts get even more ridiculous, and say the blood was up to their horses' bridles.

Writing history wasn‚Äôt viewed as a literal recounting of just the facts back then so we shouldn‚Äôt read it as such.

replies.author: @LinusE
replies.text:
A paper by Thomas F. Madden titled ‚ÄùRivers of Blood: An Analysis of One Aspect of the Crusader Conquest of Jerusalem in 1099‚Äù stated the following about this historical recollection:

‚ÄùThey pointed out that Raymond‚Äôs description of the blood up to the bridle of the horses, ‚Äòusque ad frenos equorum‚Äô is actually drawn from Revelation 14:20: ‚Äòand the wine press was trodden outside the city, and blood flowed from the wine press, as high as a horse‚Äôs bridle, for one thousand six hundred stadia‚Äô. In the Vulgate, the words used are ‚Äòusque ad frenos equorum‚Äô -the same words used by Raymond. This discovery has led most crusade historians -including myself- to view the medieval depictions of blood in the al-Aqsa Mosque or anywhere else in Jerusalem to be understood symbolically as a righteous purification of the city. This is not to deny that the massacre in 1099 was not horrible or that there was not an abundance of blood. But it is to recognize that the clerical authors of these texts were approaching their subject from other perspectives than simply a stark reporting of facts.‚Äù

Which is a view that fits the historical context of the time. The entire paper is very interesting and discusses very deeply on the topic of the blood during the massacre.

replies.text: @philknox The Kayi tribe is not the same as the Ottomans. The Ottomans claim to have originated from that tribe but the Ottoman dynasty, after which the Ottoman Empire is named, did not start until the 13th century.

replies.author: @GermanLeftist
replies.text:
@Salmon The Reconquista of the Iberian peninsula already started in the 9th century, over two hundred years prior to the crusade. And the official reasoning behind the first crusade was of defensive nature and a reaction to the call for military assistant to Pope Urban II by Byzantinian Emperor Alexios I Komnenos. Crowder and his defenders seem to draw the line here and do not further question the reason why Urban did respond to this call, especially why he did react to it by calling for the crusades. For them it should all be an easy line between cause and effect. This ignores that history seldom, if ever, works like that. A big historical event, you might even want to call it a movement, like the crusdes had more than one cause.



The Seljuq Turks had already conqured most of Anatolia two decades prior to the Council of Clermont in 1095. Back then the Pope, Gregory VII, had basically called for a crusade as well but had been opposed by European leaders who refused to go. This was prior to the Investiture Controversy between the Pope and the German king. And also prior to the death of Sultan Malik-Shah I in 1092, after which the Great Seljuq Empire broke apart. And at ruthly the same time Urban II, who become Pope in 1088, and Alexios I had started talks about ending the open schism between Rome and Byzantium that had started in 1054. There were of course other factors as well, but these are three major factors that played a role in why the First Crusade ever became a reality. It was a combination of several things that had happened in the years prior not just one.

replies.author: @philknox

replies.author: @GermanLeftist
replies.text: @philknox Of course not. But so what? To talk about Ottomans in connection to the First Crusade is still factually wrong since the Ottoman Empire nor the Ottoman dynasty did exist back then. And even if you were to use the term Ottoman as a pseudonym for the Kayi tribe, you would be wrong because the Kayi tribe were not the people at war with the Byzantian Empire at the time, that was the Seljuk Empire. Of course the Seljuks and the Kayi were both Oghuz Turks, but at this point you are at least two levels removed from the Ottomans. Bottom line, you can't use Ottomans as a pseudonym for all Turks, or even Oghuz Turks. That would be the same as using French as a pseudoynm for all Western Europeans.

replies.author: @philknox
replies.text: @ddandymann A lot of people here think that 3 Arrows has provided the counter-argument to Crowder, and that is the problem.  If you are looking for a political or military solution to the Crusades I would think that is a moot point.  Very few here have actually read the sources 3 Arrows provided. Nor will they simply because it will cause them to question their beliefs.  Reviewing what are purportedly historical posts is a worthwhile, and common practice for historians. " Hey buddy the left wing doesn't want immigration reform they want illegal immigrants to come here freely that's why a lot of liberal cities have adopted the sanctuary City plan. 
Strawman fallacy.  A SMALL minority of the left wants open borders.  You're only proving me correct by saying what you just said.


"proving my point but that you're a moron. " 
Ad Hominem Fallacy.  


"wall will stop immigration at a rate of 64%"
Wrong.  It won't stop people from coming in on planes, boats and through legal points of entry.  Tell me, how many immigrants have expired visas?  How many came here by crossing illegally (I.E. the bypassed border checkpoints entirely)?

replies.author: @TheUndeadslayer221
replies.text:
cread 61o Calling a person a moron IS an Ad hominem fallacy.  You ARE misrepresenting my position, so you ARE making a strawman fallacy.  Deal with it.


Like I said, the "Open borders" thing is only a thing among a small minority of people.  You're only proving my point.


Now please buzz off.  You're embarrassing yourself.  You're acting EXACTLY like the last Reactionary I interacted with;  Mostly Fallacies, long winded statements that don't do anything to advance a conversation and citations that either are cherry picked, incorrect or not representative of the point they're trying to make.  The first article you cited (https://www.youtube.com/redirect?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2019%2F03%2F05%2Fus%2Fcrossing-the-border-statistics.html&stzid=UgyTVvU_HyAjYt3Z8dp4AaABAg.8uZ4OLncF_j8uq5ceM1qz0&redir_token=7BcJY3n8Xr9q-OprG3uZwGgxArB8MTU1Nzc2NTU0NEAxNTU3Njc5MTQ0&event=comments) are describing the reasons why people are coming here. THE important thing here is that NEITHER of your articles defeat or debunk my original point;  A wall won't stop illegal immigration, immigration reform will (immigration reform is needed).

cread 61o The Crusades, as a whole were NOT defensive (and were ultimately a large mass of atrocities committed for stupid religious reasons).  They were offensive (there were many, but as a whole, they were offensive more so than defensive).  As for Climate Change... Who said that a Market solution was not possible?  Crowder?  Me?  No.  I concur with Potholer54 here;  A market solution to climate change is possible.   If China can do it, so to can we, The United States of America. Furthermore, last I checked, Crowder did not think Climage change was even real (the Global increase in temperature part at least).  As for the Green new deal... that's an incomplete wish list of things that would LIKE to be done to curb climate change (the paper was removed from its original source due to being incomplete).  IF the government must intervene to overcome the collective action problem, then so be it, but if BOTH a market solution and government solution is possible, then I say "Let's do it".


Have you seen Potholer54's Conservative solution to climate change video?  If not, then go watch that (there are 2 parts).


"And he's right on some regards like the polar bears there's study showing that the polar bear population is increasing and how ice in Antarctica is still growing at a net rate. "


Good guess, but actually no.  The population is growing, BUT with climate change advancing as it is, there will be no polar bears (no land to live in).  Did you not see Potholer54's response to this point in the first instance of Potholer54's response to Crowder?  Why is it that you seem to have not seen that?


Disclaimer: Potholer54 is being sourced here due to having a history of good reading comprehension and accurate reporting of information.

"Christian Lands"? Jerusalem was not "Christian lands". It had been under the control of Fatimids for centuries, and before that it was Jewish-controlled. But before the Seljuks seized it, Christians had no recorded difficulty entering the area on pilgrimages (and were allowed to build churches there); and Fatimids retook the area from the Seljuks one year before Christians began their siege and eventually-successful conquest.

replies.author: @Ioraek
replies.text:
@travishimebaugh8381 *"Actually he spent a good long time providing context/nuance that called the "retaliation" motivation into question..."*
Well put Travis, I was going to say something on that but you did a better job than I would have. 

One extra thing to add is that Three Arrows also pointed out the erroneous framing of it being a retaliatory war against an 'original crusade' by Islam, explaining the groundlessness of referring to Islam as a discrete political entity in this period. 

If Crowder had said 'a retaliatory war against the Seljuk Turks on behalf of the Byzantine Empire', he would have been closer to being accurate in a narrow sense, but even then still misleading more broadly for leaving out other critical motivations for war and conquest. 

So, to Lispin Lunatic, it's not that there's no element at all of retaliation being involved, it's that Crowder utterly misuses the concept. He falsely presents it as the exclusive reason for the crusades, and applies it in reference to his own ahistorical imagination of Islam as some consolidated international coalition.

replies.author: @Ioraek
replies.text:
I remember doing a unit about the crusades at uni several years ago (where I was doubtless fed West-hating propoganda /s). 

Found it really compelling on a number of fronts. To name a few: the various factions within the Church and the Kingdoms and their political intrigues and attempts to use the prospect (and eventuality) of war against a percieved barbaric other for their own ends; the uneasy relationship with Byzantine; and the new economies and networks which arose over the many years of crusades.

To hear Crowder's simplistic depiction of this part of history was genuinely embarrassing. But of course he's not actually here to provide a sincerely researched analysis! 

It's unsettling to me that he can present something so sloppy and amateurish, that he can continually fail to expound on points or to provide citations when the need is obvious, that he can rely on evidence which wouldn't fly in a high school essay, and yet still be so popular and successful in disseminating his message!

Yes, good point; Alexander's Greeks occupied it for awhile after taking it from Persia. Lispin Lunatic And you are taking the propaganda of the Pope, the Catholic Church, and the Crusaders at face value without applying the Ciceronian principle of "cui bono?", who benefits?, to the events. 

If the crusades were retaliation against the Seljuks, why did the sack Byzantium, the country they were supposedly retaliating for? Why were the first people they killed Jews and not Muslims? Why did they NOT return Jerusalem to the Byzantines but set up their own kingdom? Because the crusades were a cynical piece of geopolitics by the Catholic Church in order to consolidate their power over Europe and unite the continent by channeling their aggression towards an outside enemy. It would have made no difference if this outside enemy was Muslim or Christian. If the people of the Middle East had been Christians and had Islam never arose, there would still be something like the Crusades, except instead of Christianity versus Islam, it woild have been one sect of Christianity against another. The ideology of the time is but the surface excuse covering for deeper material forces driving such conflicts.

@pedroholsbach8592 
So the Iraqi invasion or Iran DID have a reasonable justification? Assad gassing his citizens DID have a reasonable justification? I don't understand your logic.
Colonization has been practiced way before your examples and is not exclusive to "white people" by any means. Are you a Christian? Do you believe god made the different races and just plopped them down where they were in 1500AD? If so, don't bother to read the next paragraph.
People have fought and conquered and colonized before we had writing to record the actions. That's how they got there. It was constant fighting and gamesmanship for territory and resources. Archaeologists have found evidence of villages being wiped out with weapons made before people figured out to affix stones to them to make points or blunt ends.
What genocides are you talking about? You think Genghis Khan and Attila the Hun just politely asked people to cut their own heads off? If you mean the genocide of the Native Americans you are misinformed. Initial contact with the Native Americans was peaceful. Unfortunately, disease killed 90 to 95% of them after contact with the Europeans. There are more Native Americans today than there were when North America was finally colonized. That isn't much of a genocide is it? Usually populations decrease in genocides. Do you know Native Americans completely exterminated the Clovis people when they came to North America? the Clovis people were the original inhabitants and the Native Americans killed every last one of them. But "white people" are bad for accidentally getting them sick?
"White people" did not invent slavery or the slave trade. Slavery is older than we can even date. They didn't even initiate the African slave trade. Muslims were there first. "But where are all the black people in Muslim countries then?" you ask. Well, the thing is that they castrated them meaning that the tribes they enslaved were completely eradicated. You do know that "black" Africans enslaved each other before Europeans ever set foot in Subsaharan Africa? You do know that after Britain and the US banned the slave trade (One of the first laws ever enacted in the new USA btw) they had to send warships to the African coast to prevent the African slave traders from continuing the practice? After all this, you must conclude that "white people" are no worse than other races. They just happened to do very well in war in the last 500 years or so due to technological advancements.
Btw, I am inferring from your name "Carlos" that you are Latin. You know it was the Latins that ravaged the Americas Southwest of the English colonies(ie almost all of it). If you are Latin American, your ancestors were responsible for that. I am Germanic and my family arrived in the USA after slavery and the Indian Wars so be careful throwing stones in a glass house!

replies.author: @pedroholsbach8592
replies.text:
@azchris1979 Warning, long reply, but you asked for it.

No, you completely misunderstood my text. I meant the polar opposite of that.

Just because other people have done it it doesn't mean what the european powers did was ok or normal by any standards. Specially considering the scale of it, no one has ever done colonization or slavery in the scale of what happened between the XV century and the XIX century.

What you're saying is frankly ridiculous. There are more jews nowadays than there has ever been in history. Does that mean the holocaust didn't happen?
Genocide, by definition, is the effort to exterminate certain ethnical group, it doesn't need to be 100% fullfilled. It's the events that happened and the intention behind them that matter, not the result necessairly. And besides, the population of Natives in the US between the years of 1491 and 1691 had decreased by about 80%. In Brazil there were thousands of ethnical groups before the Portuguese arrived, nowadays there are less than 300.

In the case of native americans in the US, the US government actively seeked to kill as many natives as possible through out the country's history, a policy that ended only around the 1900's. The US government constantly violated peace treaties with the native tribes, rounded up innocent people in camps, where disease and starvation was rampant, while denying them medicine. There are several official documents that serve as proof that the US government distributed contaminated clothes to the people in these camps, that the government killed the buffaloes in order to hinder and starve the tribes that depended on them... I can go on. Give it a read, honestly. What you're saying is utterly and almost offensively ignorant, if it unfortunately wasn't such a common misconception about what happened. 
A lot of people died for disease outbreaks, but many of these outbreaks happened because of their displacement, the destruction of their lands, their forced imprisonment in camps... so again, go back to the Holocaust, one can easily claim (and deniers often do) that a lot of the people who died were by disease and starvation.
But that doesn't mean it wasn't genocide now, does it?

I never claimed "white people" invented slavery, nor have I ever claimed they were the only ones doing it. Muslims were also not the first to trade slaves in Africa, this was going on way before Islam even existed. Romans traded slaves with African kingdoms, heck, before them the Egyptians were enslaving people... The scale of the Atlantic Slave Trade, however, was bigger than any in history, and slavery for the European powers and their colonies in the Americas was arguably the first time in history in which slavery was exclusively about skin colour, or "race". In Africa, blacks enslaved blacks, it was about ethnicity not skin colour. In Rome, you could be a brown/black skinned Roman citizen, heck, even Emperor considering Septimius Severus; and you could be a white Roman slave, enslaved because of debt, or a white German slave from a war.

My name is not "Carlos", what the fuck are you talking about. And I have German ancestry as well, look at my surname. You do know not everyone in Latin America has Spanish/Portuguese ancestry, right? Much like not everyone in the US has English. But even if my ancestors were Latin I would have no problem in recognizing the horrible shit they have done. Unlike you, apparently
It's funny tho, you have no problem recognising that the Spanish and Portuguese did horrible things to the natives(which is true), but the English and later the US were saints apparently. That's the impression you're giving me at least.
Did you know that many apologists of the colonization of South America also claim that most natives died for diseases? Funny how that works.
Also, what are you talking about "throwing stones", I didn't accuse you nor your ancestors of anything. I'm talking about history and what happened, this has fuck all to do with guilt. You're the one who decided to turn this into a "white people are the worst" thing. I never even mentioned "white people" in my response

author: @kitsuwaifune
text: Historian here. My training on the crusades doesn't make me an expert in any sense. My training was more readjusting my perceptions of the past to understand the past as a foreign land that I've never seen before. With this in mind I can't assure anyone that this video is exactly correct, however I can say you did an absolute outstanding job of at least explaining the crusades on a basic level. Most of your other videos deal with war related history which is not my field. My field is middle ages, late roman, and early Christian history. So to understand this history it was very important to understand what really happened with the crusades. This is all completely on point with what we went through at a college level. Please if you wish to counter someone on their beliefs on the crusades, share this video. I don't recommend using it in an academic sense, but I feel that's a given and not the goal for Three Arrows. So for what you were trying to accomplish you did an admiral job. Thank for your channel.

replies.author: @arminiuschieftainofthecher2780
replies.text:
Good comment; but I believe a few things need to be noted, firstly the Dark Ages were called as much due to a lack of information being recorded, but also as a result of the sort of chaos that ensued in most of Europe after the Western Roman Empire fell once and for all opening the proverbial flood gates to looting, pillaging and destruction.

Secondly, the Crusades were fought for a number of reasons by a number of people all of whom had varying degrees of moral standing; to an extent it was a retributory war against the Muslims, to an extent it was a war waged for economic interests and trade routes, generally the lower individuals of the society fought more for the former, and the higher for the latter.

Additionally while the Crusades are used as a pro-Christian, anti-Muslim historical talking point it is worth noting; much like Muslims are their own worst enemies, Christians were their own worst enemies, more Catholics were killed by Protestants and Cathars (and vice versa) than any other group, just like more Sunnis and Shiites have been attacked by Shiites and Sunnis respectively, than any other group.

replies.author: @adeleennis2255
replies.text: @alalns0ral546 It doesn‚Äôt make you right or truthful either. Just because you don‚Äôt like a source, doesn‚Äôt mean it doesn‚Äôt contain some truths. I don‚Äôt like how the Nazis obtained information on keeping downed pilots alive after recovering them from frigid North Sea waters. However, it doesn‚Äôt mean what they learned doesn‚Äôt have medical relevance today. History is not unlike science. We develop theories about events and people in the past. We look for evidence to support our theories. When new information surfaces, we (professional or hobbyist historians) adjust our perception of that event or person as needed. History isn‚Äôt static. As long as we care about discovering more about the events and people of the past, it lives, whether you like the sources that provide that life or not.

text:
My favorite research paper I've ever written was actually on one of the Crusades, one of them that isn't talked about really. Everyone talks about the Catholic vs. Muslim struggle over the Holy Land, but my favorite, one that isn't addressed as part of the Crusades in compulsory schooling and that wasn't acknowledged by the Catholic Church until 1969, was the Albigensian (or Cathar) Crusade. It took place between 1209 and 1229 AD. And it was pointless. Basically, in a bunch of central and south-eastern regions [focused on Languedoc] of France, there was people identifying as Cathars, a group of ascetic Christians who didn't think highly of the Catholic Church. So Pope Innocent III sent armies, eventually killing somewhere between 200,000 and 1,000,000 people of the area. It was one of the events used to explain historical instances of genocide in the book that coined the term (by Raphael Lemkin) and the Crusade included such gems as the sentiment/potential statement "Kill them all, God will know his own" (the origin of that meme); a massacre of 20,000 men, women, and children at once; murdering priests in front of and atop their altars (Christian altars, I'll remind you); an army forcing the entirety of Carcassonne to flee either naked or in just their underwear (depending on the account); and multiple sieges decided by cutting off water supplies shortly followed by burning Cathars alive.


The Crusades were horrendous, and defending them from the Catholic perspective is, for lack of a better term, evil.


Edit: Three Arrows mentions it a little bit! I know he doesn't cover it much since it wasn't carried out against Muslims, but I'm glad it's covered since it's what I call a 'lost genocide', or a genocide that's been almost completely erased from the public consciousness (because, I mean, the only reason anyone brings it up is to criticize Christianity, which no one is all that interested with in the west).

replies.author: @DisorderlyFashion
replies.text:
@azchris1979 you could also look at the beginning of the Crusades from of secular perspective. Byzantines were losing ground against a rival empire (turks), called on the Pope - then an influential player in secular politics as well as religious - for help. Pope sees this a good opportunity to unite Europe against a common foe and enhance papal influence with the Byzantines, and things spiralled out of control from there.

Obviously most people who joined the Crusades set out with a religious goal in mind but the macro-motivations were fairly secular. Byzantines wanted some western mercenaries to take some land back and got a religious army instead. This interpretation isn't necessarily absolutely correct but I make it point out that there are a lot of different ways to look at history, and that simple readings of History are rarely sufficient.

replies.author: @ninjacats1647
replies.text:
@dinospumoni5611 

I'm fairly critical of modern day Islam, but I also believe in straight up reforming the 10th amendment (arguably the single biggest Constitutional reform I would do - I also agree with the general international consensus against birth right citizenship as well - which means I agree with Trump on that specific policy point). Mind you, I see the 10th amendment as a gateway to cultural relativism, which I oppose when the cultural relativistic point in question allows for morally egregious actions. 

Of course the problem of the 10th amendment's history in the United States has nothing to do with the moral quandaries of Islamic oppression of gays, atheists and apostates, but rather the cultural relativism that the 10th amendment was used to enable moral evils such as slavery and Jim Crow in American history. And I'm not even close to being an SJW, in fact I generally oppose much of the new left sans the economic populist angle which I'm neutral towards or somewhat favor. 

The abolitionist position towards slavery was essentially anti-relativistic at its core. The movement campaigned that slavery was wrong period, and that no culture could rightfully justify its existence. 

Perhaps I'm stretching things a bit here, because I've never heard anybody actually point out that the 10th amendment acts as an enabler of cultural relativism, except maybe Noam Chomsky in some of his arguments, and my memory is fuzzy here. The 10th amendment should have been written more carefully, and should have limited the rights of the states further - to preemptively prevent them from allowing cultural systems such as slavery to flourish. But in the end imo, the 10th amendment gave the states too much power.

replies.author: @LinusE
replies.text:
@daringiconoclast6547  The South seceeded because of slavery. It‚Äôs in the secession documents. And 2% owned slaves yes, but the soldiers supported slavery. In the South, slavery wasn‚Äôt just some economic corporation. It was religiously, and (at the time) scientifically proven to be the state of African Americans and it is what Confederates believed, whether they were poor farmers or plantation owners.

And yes, the Northerners weren‚Äôt anti-racists, a lot of people at the time were racists. But the point about Lincoln saying he would keep the Union without abolishing slavery, this is sort of taken out of context and it doesn‚Äôt prove your point neither because the South had seceeded regardless. The context in which he said so was in an letter, warning for extremely long citation but here it goes:

‚ÄùMy paramount object in this struggle is to save the Union, and is not either to save or to destroy slavery. If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone, I would also do that. What I do about slavery and the colored race, I do because I believe it helps to save thise Union; and what I forbear, I forbear because I do not believe it would help to save the Union.‚Äù
- From Abraham Lincoln to Horace Greeley [Newspaper Clipping]1, August 22, 1862

This letter has seemed disingenuous to some. In it, however, Lincoln makes it clear to the public that though he considers his primary constitutional duty to be to save the Union, partial or even total emancipation might well be the necessary means to attain that end. Lincoln needed to make his position completely clear without tipping his hand on emancipation prematurely. He couldn‚Äôt appear as a ‚Äùradical abolisher‚Äù before he could get the emancipation proclamation through.

And the South had not abolished slavery during the Civil War. I think you‚Äôre referring to the emancipation proclamation? The proclamation only said that the States that uphold slavery are in active rebellion against the United States and that the armies of the United States will fight and act for the freedom of said slaves. It only made the war officially about freeing slaves. And if the South had abolished slavery, why didn‚Äôt just Jefferson Davis or Robert E. Lee surrender? Why did they continue to fight? 

I‚Äôm very sorry for the long post

replies.text:
I can't speak for the whole of Christendom, but in my part of the woods, during the numerous wars between Scotland and England - both Christian countries from the early middle age period onward at least, churches and religious institutions were regularly pillaged and destroyed by both sides. See for example Melrose Abbey in the Scottish Borders: Pillaged and burned by Edward II in 1322, burnt by Richard II in 1385. Lindisfarne had to be fortified against Scottish raiding etc...Then we have the protestant reformation, starting with the dissolution of the monasteries (cash grab by Henry VIII and other unscrupulous nobility) and vandalism and destruction caused by all sides of churches in the Wars of the three Kingdoms in the 17th Century. 


I am sure others in Western Europe have similar histories of desecration of religious houses and buildings that occurred in wars and other movements between solely Christian powers.

replies.author: @sammosaurusrex
replies.text:
@azchris1979 You linked a battle from literally 400 years before the crusades.
It's like saying "Remember the war of 1812? Better march on London before they start impressing sailors on our merchant vessels again!"
The first line of that article says "There is little dispute that the battle helped lay the foundations of the Carolingian Empire and Frankish domination of Europe for the next century." That means that, by the time of the crusades, the Carolingian empire had developed from that battle, waxed to be the dominant power in Western Europe, fractured under civil war, reunited briefly, and returned to a state of warring factions, competing interests, and shifting alignments, with 200 years left STILL until the first crusade.

As for Muslim conquests, the caliphate which conquered Spain and held the most territory of any caliphate also no longer existed, nor had it for about 350 years (see: The age of the United States) at the time of the Crusades. There was still warring between Christian and Muslim kingdoms in Spain, but there was also alliances between Christian and Muslim kingdoms in Spain when their interests were in alignment or they had mutual foes. The crusades revived the idea of a holy war of expulsion of Muslims from Spain for the first time since the Umayyads were successfully repelled from France a full 400 years prior.

Finally, the first crusade "being caused by the growing power of the Seljuk Turks" is a sensible read on history, one which recognizes specific regional interests and factions (both Christian and Muslim) competing for power, but is so far removed from "the Muslims had to be driven back, Christendom was in danger of being overrun," I'm struggling to see how you think it supports your point.

Your details do nothing to undermine my point. Muslims had a centuries long expansionist policy BEFORE the crusades. They were at it yet again when Constantinople begged the Westerners for help. Maybe the Byzantines were full of crap and exaggerated how bad it was to con them into helping. I am starting to see where we disagree though. You seem to be inferring that my position is that Christendom was in imminent danger of being annihilated. I have said nothing to that effect and I do not believe they were capable of that although they did try later. I just said that the Muslims were the aggressors. John Rambo would say they drew first blood.  
I am not even saying that crusaders were "good guys" like GI JOE or something. My point and Crowder's point is basically, "Hey, turnabout is fair play.", "Whats good for the goose is good for the gander.", "You better be prepared to finish a fight if you start it.", "You reap what you sow.", etc. 
If someone's point was "Jihadi AND Crusader ideology is stupid and violent" you would get no argument from me! I only scoff when people act like the crusaders just randomly decided, "Hey, lets go kill some innocent people that look and believe differently than us."
Maybe you need a little context about Crowder. He has a longstanding beef with Cenk Uyger. He was featured in this response video saying something like, "They didn't go up there, you came down here!" as if Jerusalem was their ancestral homeland or something. So the video he made was to rebut that lie showing that indeed the Muslims DID "go up there." You are making it out to be more than it is.

replies.author: @sammosaurusrex
replies.text:
azchris1979 Ah, ok, yes I guess we do have some common ground here then, though I still disagree.

I think Cenk and Steven are both arrogant know-nothing grandstanders, and I guess my distaste for them really shines through

My full position is that the Pope is the seized on the threat to the Byzantines (whose weakening must have made him gleeful at the time) to expand his authority and military capability, invoke in the minds of European leaders their Christian identity, and try to seize power over the Eastern Orthodox Church, by calling for conquest of the Holy land.

I don‚Äôt think that can be referred to as self defense in any context. The conquest was not motivated by worries about the expanding Seljuks, but rather a predation of the Catholic Church to use war to increase their status and potentially reclaim authority over their religious rivals in the Byzantine empire by capitalizing on the Empire‚Äôs weakness.

Thus, I totally reject Crowder‚Äôs ‚Äúit was a response to the Muslim crusades‚Äù as ridiculous.

Still, I do condemn the expansions of the Umayyads, the Crusades, the conquests led by Andrew Jackson, Napoleon, and Hitler, and all other expansionist leaders, factions, and nations.

replies.text:
‚Äã@mrsuspicious1743 I'm not sure why we need to constantly dissect and heavy-handedly critique uses of this word ... even just the "neo" part of it... Frankly, having to explain this over and over to people who arguably might actually know better strikes me as incredibly bizarre, a bit discouraging, infuriatingly distracting, and ultimately empty.  But here.
Seemed like Ivan was saying religion is a neo-fascist scam.  I don't quite get how that's weird...  maybe the "neo" part?  Since religions are ancient?  But they're alive and well now, and Ivan uses the word "is," as in present tense... so I'm not sure why "neo" would be offensive in that context.
As far as the concept of "neo-fascism" itself, as opposed to regular-ass fascism, it seems the vital distinction is that neo-fascism would be global.  As in, a type of fascism born out of neoliberal economic policy.  With neoconservative values.

replies.author: @KilijHistoryKlcTarihi
replies.text: @Benji567891 The main issue when calling it a genocide is mainly that the supposed killings that happened against the Armenians happened mainly in the eastern provinces of the Empire. The Russian Empire and its Armenian militias that they armed occupied most East Anatolia. 1917 -1918 is when the Ottomans captured the Eastern provinces back and had to give up most of the land again during Sevr. The Union and progress committee lost its power during this era and most fled the country or helped with the indepence war. The conflict between the Armenians and Turks in these provinces is not really a genocide as both parties killed one another. The same happened during 1919 - 1922 with the Greeks, as it was conflict amongst ethnic groups. Killing ethnic Turks in Van, Bitlis, Malazgirt, Satak etc and of course the Turks didn't keep it clean either.

Although I do think a fair number of the mistakes that crowder makes are benign, not all of them are benign some are pretty ugly.

bh5496 honestly I think I said it in a different thread but I realized that yeah I was being way too lenient and charitable with Crowder. I have a tendency to take the shadow of something someone I have sympathies with says, and find the thing that is accurate in them and ignore the rest. It‚Äôs a problem I‚Äôve been working on as I try to become more intellectually honest. 

As for Crowder I would guess that it isn‚Äôt deliberate lying so much as it is an example of rushed work outside of one‚Äôs area of expertise combined with personal biases that are sufficiently strong as to shift one‚Äôs reading of accuse events into facsimiles of what they actually were and filling in the blank space of your knowledge with what you are pretty sure you know but actually don‚Äôt. 

I try to give even my political opposition the benefit of the doubt in that respect. I find most people don‚Äôt deliberately lie so much as their biases warp their own reality and they present that warped reality to their viewers.

replies.author: @claudiu-mihaipuiu1221
replies.text:
@ishitrealbad3039 Even the most cursory searches of the First Crusade will have these oaths pointed out. It was one of the conditions of the emperor Alexios Komnenos in order for him to ferry troops over the Bosphorus strait and into Anatolia so they could head to the Holy Land itself.

Heck, Alexios Komnenos had gotten this ball rolling by asking help from the Pope in order to reconquer some territories. However, he expected a few thousand mercenaries not several armies worth of crusaders trying to take the Holy Land, so in order to actually get them to return their lands, the emperor extracted oaths out of most of the main Crusader princes (except Bohemond and Raymond of Toulouse).

Edit: As for the source, it's the book called the Alexiad, written by the daughter of the aforementioned emperor Alexios Komnenos and basically chronicles his interactions with the Crusaders among other things.

Edit 2: Literally the first engagement of the Crusader Princes involved the help of the Byzantines during the Siege of Nicaea by sending both troops and sending ships on logs to blockade the lake the city was situated on to prevent supplies being sent via the lake.

The Seljuks did invade the ERE. This is, after all, the event that was used at the time by the Pope  to start the Crusades. I did not, at any point, claim otherwise. However, a "defensive" war would see the combined Christian armies fighting together against the Seljuks to retake the lost lands of Anatolia. This wasn't quite what happened, was it?

As for Jerusalem being Christian, that's frankly a point against considering the Crusades defensive. Firstly, it proves there wasn't a serious persecution of Christians in Muslim-controlled territory, since if there was, Christians wouldn't be the majority in a city that was controlled for centuries by Islamic Caliphates. Secondly, what does this say about the Crusaders, Defenders of Christendom, who slaughtered the people of the city, who shared their Faith? Who were they defending, if they were slaughtering Christians?

Bohemond of Taranto *explicitly* never intended to give any land to the Byzantines. His intentions were to carve out an Eastern Kingdom to himself (which he did, becoming Prince of Antioch). He had, in fact, for that exact same purpose, carried out incursions against the Byzantines before, which was part of why he had to take an oath once he joined the Crusade, otherwise Emperor Alexios would have no reason to trust him or allow him passage through his lands. Also important is that there was no pact between Bohemond and Jonh Komnenus during the first crusade, given that the latter was a nine-years-old boy at the time.

I don't see how the Armenians come into play, unless it's about the Eastern Orthodox Christians I mentioned. You see, I was talking about Jerusalem and the Levant, there, where the Crusaders created their own Catholic kingdoms. Armenia simply has nothing to do with my comment, but hey, you're right there: The Armenians did ally themselves to the Crusaders. You're right about something! Great Work! Now you just have to keep it up!

-> The Jews

*sigh*

I wasn't being entirely serious when I brought them up. I brought them up because the defense most used is "The Crusaders were fighting a defensive/reconquest war!"

I was jokingly saying they should give the land back to the Jews, since they were the ones there before the Romans conquered, pillaged and genocided them; I was not seriously saying that should have happened. 

However, it was there for a reason: To show the absurdity of laying claim to a land that hasn't belong to you, your people, or whoever you're claimed it would rightfully belong to, after it hasn't been theirs for centuries (ergo: Reconquest. You get that? When someone steals from you and you take it back? Is that concept rocket science for you?)

The issue here, beyond how long the lands had belonged to Muslim rulers, is that a war of reconquest is to take back a land for the people or countries that used to live there. Bohemond wasn't from Antioch, his family had never been from anywhere near it. Baldwin had no claim to Edessa. Godfrey wasn't from a Levantine family, nor of a line of Kings of Jerusalem. The idea that the Kingdom of Jerusalem was reconquered is baffling in itself; there had never been a Kingdom of Jerusalem before, and the closest thing to that were the Jewish kingdoms of Judea.

This isn't a reconquest; it's a war of conquest, which isn't defensive by definition. Come on, we're talking about History here, not rocket science! It isn't that complex!

But please, do "correct" my points. Just make sure that, when you do, you actually base your arguments on actual historical fact ;)

Have a good day yourself.

replies.text:

If you should remember, after a coupe regarding the shia/sunni problem in Egypt, the new state started to chase, murder, and enslave pilgrims.


Jerusalem is the city of Jesus, so it belong to Christianity.


"This isn't a reconquest; it's a war of conquest, which isn't defensive by definition. Come on, we're talking about History here, not rocket science! It isn't that complex!"

Lol, so it is rocket science to you m8. Do you seriously believe defense is only to guard yourself? Have you never practizes any form of martial art? Defense is rejecting attacks and winning, not hidding at your mother's skirt.


I made allmmy basis on historical facts bro. And I know a thing or two about warfare and the difference between defensive and agressive wars. Aggressive war would be to take what is not yours, not retake what is tightfully yours.

replies.author: @henriquepacheco7473
replies.text:
@JuanJos√©O√±ate-m4e Oh, so you're justifying the Crusades with the Bible now? Well, my good sir, I hate to inform this to you, but Jesus never held temporal power. Jesus never ruled over any lands. Therefore the "Kingdom of Jerusalem" in the bible is almost as much of a real, provable country that justifies a war of reconquest as Narnia.


To say that a holy book or a significant event in a religion's history is a valid claim to a city or territory would allow anyone to create their own religion and suddenly have a claim on any land. Therefore, Jerusalem being the city of Jesus has absolutely no importance, and does not justify a war fought to conquer it. If it did, then Christian countries should probably prepare for war against Israel, they're Jews after all, and we must reclaim the holy land.



Despite what you believe, I did study the Crusades to a certain extent; I can't claim expertise, but I doubt you can either, so we're back to step 0 here. The Armenians were mostly located in Asia minor and the northernmost areas of what you could conceivably call the Levant. In fact, Armenian Cilica, which you mentioned, was in practice entirely within Asia Minor. Yet, it still does not matter as far as what I had said. I was talking about the states created in the Levant by the Crusader Princes, EG Baldwin and Godfried.


Finally, since you mentioned it, I do actually practice a martial art. I do not believe defense is to only guard something. I know that sometimes, you have to attack. I never claimed otherwise, and I sincerely do not see how you could come to the conclusion that I did, or at least that I gave this impression. 


However, the Crusades were not defensive. They were a war of conquest. It is not defensive or a reconquest to try to capture land that has never belonged to you, and hasn't belonged to anyone even arguably similar to you (kind-of-sharing their faith, in this case) for over three centuries. If it was, then I guess the United Kingdom would be justified in trying to reconquer the USA right now. Spain would be justified to go on a reconquest against Mexico, Central America and most of South America (including Brazil, since it has taken bits and pieces of land that belonged to Spain all the way back in colonization), Germany to do so against France and Belgium and Poland and Russia, Austria to go absolutely ham in central and eastern Europe, and it goes on like that. 


It is not defensive nor reconquest to take lands you have no claim on, apart from a book most of the world doesn't believe to be true anyways, and make your own kingdoms and principalities on it.


As for preventing/being hostile to pilgrimage, it's far from enough to qualify a war asdefensive. I am not claiming they were an act of aggression without any possible offense or any provocation, a mindless and mad act of savage brutality, at all for Christians to decide to go to war, but to classify it as defensive based on that would be absolutely ludicrous.


Finally; the Treaty of Devol, which is the "pact" Bohemond supposedly signed with John Komnenos (it was actually with Alexios, but to try to discredit it just because of this would be more pedantic that what even I allow myself to be).


It was signed in 1108, between Alexios and Bohemond, years after the First Crusade, and it had provisions that would see the Principality of Antioch to become a Vassal of the Byzantine Emperor and later be assimilated. It happened after a war between Bohemond and the Byzantine Empire, in which he failed in his attempt to attack Constantinople through the same route he had taken alongside his Father's armies in his youth. While his army laid siege to Dyrrachium, his camp got blockaded by Alexios army, and he was forced to negotiate.


The result was the treaty of Devol, which was slanted to favour the ERE. Bohemond was made the Emperor's vassal, forced to cede disputed landsand admit a greek patriarch in Antioch (Religious suppression against the Eastern orthodox faith? On MY Antioch? ...It's more likely than you think) and would receive a monetary compensation from the Emperor. Bohemond, however, never returned to Antioch, and with his death, the treaty was rendered null and void.


This is the only pact or Treaty Bohemond ever signed with any Byzantine leadership. It also happened in 1108, years after the Prince's Crusade. He never intended to give the ERE a single bit of land, and when he would finally be forced to do so, he went into a self-imposed exile, from which only his corpse returned, thus making the treaty that would give back the ERE's land null. Truly a man who intended only to recover the land lost by the Byzantines, and not someone who wanted their own kingdom.


But sure, all you're saying is based on historical facts. I won't even deny that, they are. I don't doubt it. It just isn't supported by the historical facts it is based on.

replies.author: @henriquepacheco7473
replies.text:
@JuanJos√©O√±ate-m4e Since you claim expertise, would you share your studies? I mean, if they were published, it should be possible to find them online. Can you at least provide me the titles?


Yes, Jerusalem had been for centuries a hot-spot of strife, and would remain so for even more centuries. It's kind of what happens when it's a holy city for two different major religions (and a third, minor one). People want control over the holy land, since that would be very prestigious, and also allow them to control access to it (and apply taxes to visitors, etc. It's pretty profitable, really).


Religious strife is just one facet of religious strife, and religion being involved does not change the morality of the acts. However, given your reaction, I must assume you're Spanish, so you're not the one I should converse with about Colonialism, you will be irreparably biased anyways.


Bohemond was a special man. Exceptional among the Crusader leadership for his competence, ambitious, loved by his subordinates, etc. Apparently exceptionally good-looking amongst Crusaders, too; the Emperor's daughter, Anna Komnene, in fact, expressed her admiration for him specifically, in the Alexiad.
All of this, however, does not change that he wanted to give no land to the Komnenoi, the ones who would have any claim on it, and none of his Crusading allies did, either. They weren't reconquering, if they were the land they took in the first crusade would have been ceded peacefully and willingly to the ERE.


My subjective, atheist, modern - but moral, thank you very much - views, were not used to interpret history except in matters wholly unrelated to the point of view of the medieval Christians, such as "Were the Crusades defensive?" The moral standards which applied at the time make no difference, the medieval point of view doesn't matter. This isn't "Did the Crusaders consider themselves defenders of Christendom?", because they certainly did and questioning that would be an example of - if you forgive my slip into vulgarity - idiotic headassery.


Does what the Crusaders though and their moral views define whether the Crusades were defensive? If yes, then we have to consider: The Nazis were doing just the right thing, because they believed so; The Japanese were right to slaughter millions of Chinese civilians, because they thought they were weak scum and deserved it. These people also believed their cause, and all they did was because of their cause. The same excuse can be used here.


Oh but what is this? Religious strife and political strife can't be compared? Well, I entirely disagree with that, but it's all the same. By your logic, ISIS is fighting a defensive war, because A: The West and Syria and whoever else attacked and held land in Iraq and the Levant; B:Their struggle is religious in nature, since they wish for their religious view to prevail; C: They see themselves as righteous defenders of the Will of Allah, as they are the ones who have the correct interpretation of the Quran and who are doing Allah's will in trying to form a new Caliphate, in lands that the Caliphs and Islam have claim to.


I don't think you believe that, so why (apart from your personal religious bias, which shouldn't be used in History) would the Crusaders be any different?


Could it, perhaps, be that you are letting your religious bias guide you, when you shouldn't be judging others through the lens of your subjective, modern, western, religious, questionably moral views?

author: @rouchenelvann
text: I actually have watched much of crowders content over the last year, and found much of it informative (considering my lack of perspective on many of the issues), so to come across this video was uncomfortable (as many things are that disrupt ones current place of comfort and understanding.) Thankfully, I‚Äôm also one who is always willing to revisit topics and attempt to understand all points of views. That being said, I‚Äôm grateful for this video. To me, it doesn‚Äôt matter who you support or are against, bad information should be contended with, and good information should be advanced and conceded. I actually enjoy longer videos like this one, because I assume that information will not be brushed over or oversimplified in the attempt to be concise. All in all, thank you for taking the time to respond. Unlike the many who have commented merely criticizing crowder, I have no personal issue with the man. Bad information is just that, and I think we all have biases that keep us from seeing clearly on certain topics. Thanks again for taking the time to research and gather the information, as well as put things into perspective.

My issues with Crowder come from how often he is wrong, to the point that he either doesn't research at all, or, more likely, is deliberately spreading misinformation. In his website, for example, he hosts many articles claiming that climate change/global warming isn't real, but said articles use absurd claims. One such article, that I'm remembering off the top of my head, said that glaciers in Greenland were growing. The data seemed, at first glance, to support that. The issue was, that data went from something like August or September of an year to February of the next. The same source, taking a few years into account, would show that glacier rapidly shrinking, but hey, it grew in Winter, so it certainly must be always growing!


There were several other instances I saw of him lying or at least spreading misinformation in order to further his agenda in his actual videos, and this is why I have a hard time respecting the man, but I hope you can forgive me not remembering any specific one right now. I don't exactly watch his videos often - or at all, really.


You seem like a reasonable sort, so if you have the time, I'd recommend always double-checking what Crowder says, or at least not blindly believing it as truth. He very often spreads misleading information on the topics of migration, climate change and Islam. While I personally don't much care about the last one, and wouldn't mind if it stopped existing, it's still worth knowing Crowder is probably at least blowing it out of proportion when he brings it up.

replies.author: @rouchenelvann

I personally don‚Äôt buy climate change hype, and it has nothing to do with Crowder, but rather what I have been able to ascertain via my own diligence. But I digress. I honestly think that this channel does the same thing that you charge crowder for in simply trying to further an agenda. I‚Äôve been following and it seems to merely be an anti-right/anti-conservative channel. I could lead with that, but I don‚Äôt want to go off track from your actual comment and points made. It does stand to be noted that the same tactics seem to be present on both sides. For example, I‚Äôve watched videos from this channel where the entirety of the information used to support the premise is all left wing sources, some of which have been caught outright manipulating data and information. So it would appear that many of us are simply attempting to further our own agenda. Honestly, it bothers me both ways. I‚Äôd rather a channel that opposes bad information where it is found, and promotes good information and research where it is found. This channel is pretty much anti crowder, Shapiro, etc., as if those men have not presented good information on many occasions. There‚Äôs no balance anywhere it seems. But I appreciate you taking the time to comment. I apologize if I‚Äôve misinterpreted your positions or created a strawman at any point. Forgive me for the delayed response.

replies.author: @rouchenelvann
replies.text:
A a , I appreciate the response. I don‚Äôt think that it is accurate to state that crowder and others aren‚Äôt willing to have a debate simply because a debate was canceled, considering that there‚Äôs a sufficient number of debates where the people that you named are indeed debating and/or attempting to have a dialectic with those who they oppose. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair to point to an example of a canceled debate and use that to suggest that they aren‚Äôt willing to debate, or that they don‚Äôt debate people with whom they have opposing views. Likewise, to say that they ‚Äúoften cancel their debates‚Äù without a sufficient body of examples of such. There are men such as Jordan Peterson who has effectively responded to many intelligent left wing proponents and has not dodged a debate. I‚Äôve also notice many people who subscribe to this channel claim that crowder only debates college kids, which is quite frankly false. These are, in my opinion, criticisms that are leveled in an attempt to discredit the individual without fairly assessing the individual, their merits, or the reasons behind certain actions (such as why much of the ‚Äúchange my mind‚Äù series is held on college campuses.) a sort of ‚ÄúTexas sharpshooter fallacy,‚Äù if you will. I will say that If they are indeed dodging debates, then they should be called on it publicly and persistently until they measure up to their own claims of objectivity and willingness to debate. I don‚Äôt support cowardice in the least. 

I‚Äôm not familiar with the individual that you named, but once I post my reply I will take the time to look at their channel. I‚Äôm not really into pro left or pro right. Many of my positions don‚Äôt come from Crowders videos or Ben Shapiro. I research the issue for myself. And I find in many cases much that both parties are overlooking and/or areas where both parties refuse to be reasonable or concede. I think that‚Äôs why seeing channels like this one are so frustrating to me, once I realize that it‚Äôs merely ‚Äúpro ‚Äî‚Äú and not just a central location for truth and objectivity. But I digress. 

Again, I appreciate your reply. I‚Äôm interested in your thoughts/response to my comment. Past all of the videos, the pro right or pro left arguments, and the debate dodging, I think it‚Äôs moments like this (where the average individual, such as you and I can come together and discuss these things respectfully and without animus) that matters most.

replies.author: @Aa-dc2xu
replies.text:
@rouchenelvann What I'm about to say is simply my opinion and your free to disagree. The reason Kyle and I believe that Trump would have a harder time against Bernie compared to Bloomberg is pretty simple. Bloomberg is trying to buy himself into the Whitehouse and he doesn't really have any policies which would be popular for your regular people.  Bernie is the most popular Democrat and I believe he's also the most popular politician in the US if I remember correctly. 

One of the reasons Kyle believes that Trump won 2016 over Hillary is that he had populist policies mixed in with his more conservative policies. Stuff like ending the wars and getting rid of NAFTA for example. Me and him see Trump as more of a fake populist as many of his populist policies which have carried him haven't really been taken to fruition (Trump has increased drone strikes by 426% over Obama as well as not pulling out the US forces from any country - he even blocked legislation to end the Saudi lead Yemeni genocide, and his new NAFTA agreement isn't that much different from the previous one, plus other examples). Whereas on the other hand Bernie's policies are widely popular and have proven to work in other countries. 70% of US citizens want medicare for all, 62% want tuition free public college and 90% want universal child care. I live in the UK and many of the things Bernie is proposing already exist here and every other country in the developed world. If Bernie's policies are socialist policies, then the UK, Canada, Denmark, France and every other developed country is a socialist country.

I myself am a Muslim, I respect Christian's very much, and we believe in Jesus too. Due to my Muslim upbringing I'm not too fond of the progressive views on Abortion or LGBTQ stuff. But I agree with other social and foreign policies. In our religion, we believe that it's a good thing to look after the more disadvantaged in society, and I believe that's the same with Christianity. That's why the more social democratic policies of the Bernie attract me.

Anyway, thanks for reading this way too long post.

replies.author: @rouchenelvann
replies.text:
A a , I don‚Äôt mind reading long replies. Lol. On face, I can appreciate the points you made. I do disagree with most of the points you presented, though, because I think they‚Äôre either mischaracterizations (such as the statement that if bernies policies are socialist, then the Uk, Canada, Denmark, etc. are as well.) This simply isn‚Äôt true. Bernie himself supports socialism and calls on places like Denmark for support, while leaders of Denmark have publicly criticized bernies assertion that they are such. They are market economies. If Bernie doesn‚Äôt understand the difference, and calls on them as support for his socialist policies, then he either doesn‚Äôt properly research his references, or he‚Äôs doing an intellectual sleight of hand. Furthermore, there is a difference between having social services and being a socialist. That‚Äôs the difference with what Bernie is perusing vs what we see in other countries which aren‚Äôt actually socialist countries, or countries who‚Äôs wealth was gained by free market practices, and are not attributed as the product of socialism. I think we should be very careful not to conflate social services with outright socialism, which is what it seems you‚Äôre saying by stating that if a policy is considered a socialist policy, then the country is by default socialist. That would be the same as me stating that because much of the developed world holds similar policies and stances to America, that they are thereby constitutional republics. My apologies if I am misconstruing what you‚Äôre stating. I don‚Äôt mean to do so. 

Also, the numbers you presented are incorrect, to date. Only 50 percent of American adults support Medicare for all. 73 percent would prefer a government plan that would rival private insurance plans, but would not want private insurance plans to be abolished (which is what Bernie proposes.) I believe that stat you‚Äôre referring to was from 2018. Similarly with the other numbers you referenced. Also, such policies are economically unsustainable. It seems to be the case that where there is single payer healthcare to the degree that Bernie is advocating, then the quality of healthcare falls and access to certain treatments are rendered unattainable. I will acknowledge that I‚Äôm speaking to what I have read and heard, and not necessarily to what I have personally been able to ascertain, so I may be wrong. I believe Thomas Sowell has spoken regarding many of the policies that Bernie espouses and the detriment thereof. 

As far as looking out for the disadvantaged is concerned, I‚Äôm not sure how that equates to a support of socialism. As a Christian, I do help to provide for those who are truly disadvantaged, as the scriptures require. But I‚Äôm also aware that a man that doesn‚Äôt work should also not eat, having the ability to do so but exercising slothfulness or plundering others. And I think that, from what I‚Äôve heard from Bernie and others, they don‚Äôt propose a way of ensuring that those who wait to plunder don‚Äôt become the greater beneficiaries of these socialist policies. Furthermore, I think the greatest way to help the disadvantaged is by creating more opportunities for them to lift themselves out of their situation. Merely giving free stuff rarely ever changes a persons situation for the better. We see people who win the lottery often end up worse off than before they won. Affordable housing complexes are often the most unappreciated by the very tenants who are benefiting from the low cost. And I could go on. Giving things for free often results in a lack of appreciation and taking advantage of the thing being given. But it also isn‚Äôt free. And I don‚Äôt see Bernie discussing how he‚Äôs really going to pay for the cost. Taxing the top 1 percent sounds good, but it‚Äôs unrealistic, and still wouldn‚Äôt suffice. You‚Äôd literally have to tax the common worker substantially. It‚Äôs a system designed to eat itself, from what I‚Äôve looked at. 

Honestly, I may disagree with where you stand, but I appreciate the level of thought and consideration that you‚Äôve placed into coming to your decision. Many that I‚Äôve come across haven‚Äôt given sufficient thought and consideration into the people and policies that they support. We share a similar fondness, or rather, a similar lack thereof, for abortion and lgbtq stuff. And our faith shows also that we share many values. So I don‚Äôt want to get too caught up in where we disagree, without taking the time to acknowledge and focus on where we do have much in agreement. I appreciate your time and patience with me. Sometimes my thoughts aren‚Äôt as coherent as I would hope.

replies.author: @k.v.7681
replies.text:
@rouchenelvann  an A a, I've been reading your exchange with interest. It was curteous, cool headed and I would like to congratulate you both. These things are rare these days, even more so in a youtube comment section. I would, however (or rather, because of that), like to ask you a genuine question. How do you manage to act upon tought and facts for your politcal leanings and still act, on the other hand, upon faith of your respective religions? For instance on the matter of debates around LGBT matters?


Also, a slight data point that may be of interest about people taking advantage of the system: In France, where safety nets are in place for people who lost a job, struggle to find one, it has been proven that only 3% of people recieving benefits are taking advantage of the system in a delibarate fashion, and lose their rights to benefits if proven to take advantage of those rights. Meaning 97% of people who get those benefits genuinely need them. There are also studies that show a lot of people do not seek these benefits by fear of reducing their image to society, or simply because they would feel like their self-worth is dimished. Most human beings have a certain pride that pushes them to accomplish something, or makes them refuse to show the slightest weakness (financial status is a big deal in society). Being without a job is a rather depressing affair for a lot of people.
