replies.author: @rouchenelvann
replies.text:
K. V. 

As it pertains to my political leanings and my faith, I honestly haven‚Äôt found an area in which the two have come at odds. As it pertains the lgbt community specifically, though my religion deems the lifestyle sinful, I don‚Äôt stand against it simply because the scriptures tell me it‚Äôs wrong. I believe that if a religion, or more precisely, if God declares something to be wrong, then there is ample evidence outside of scriptures to show the detriment of such a thing. So considering the many areas where a homosexual lifestyle is bad for the person involved, the children involved, birth rates, personal mental health, the society as a whole, etc., I stand in opposition to the lifestyle, while still being able to love and be there for the person in their time of need, and allowing them the choice to live their life as they see fit. But my stances have only been settled on which a great deal of thought and deep considerations. I take months, and in some cases years, trying to truly understand a thought, belief, teaching, etc. I honestly think that much of the debates around many hot topics comes from people who have not given honest and considerable thought to what they support or oppose. And I can understand why. It‚Äôs uncomfortable. I know the discomfort that comes with not only questioning a belief, but also changing a belief that was held so close to the heart. 

As far as your comment about people not abusing the system, in order to have a proper critique, or to support the position you hold, I would need to see exactly which studies you‚Äôre referring to. I‚Äôd need to be able to examine the measuring rod. Are these subjective studies? If not, what are the objective measures? How are they determining that only 3% are purposely taking advantage? How are they ascertaining that the other 97% aren‚Äôt? Etc. These are the immediate questions that come to mind, but as of now I‚Äôll simply have to yield to what you are stating as being true, at least in regard to the studies you‚Äôre referring to. I do, however, see a much different picture here in America. Stay in any low income housing and it is common practice that the majority of people are taking advantage of the system. Many of them need it, but only because they aren‚Äôt doing what is necessary to lift themselves out of their position. To many here it is a crutch, not a safety net. Yes, many of them fill out applications for employment, go to interviews, and other things which would seem to indicate genuine effort, but they are doing so out of necessity, not because they actually want to free themselves from the assistance. I‚Äôve seen this done for many years. I also do not agree that people generally have such pride that they don‚Äôt want to use these systems. I think that goes against human nature, which is to take advantage. The history of the world has been conquest and taking as much as can be taken. Yes, being without a job is a very trouble affair for many, but there are also a great many who are ok with not having a job, and plundering those who do, as well as taking advantage of systems in place. 
I don‚Äôt want to state too much and not give you an opportunity to respond. Thank you again for your kind words, and for furthering the discussion in such a manner. Looking forward to your response.

replies.author: @k.v.7681
replies.text:
@rouchenelvann Thank you for your answer, and you are welcome to the words, they don't cost me anything and were deserved :)
For the number, I can't recall the exact study, it was a couple of years ago on a ministerial report (the ministry of work). The number stuck with me because we were in the middle of a reform regarding the partaining laws and it was quite a hot topic in the country. As for the tools used to obtain such a number: When without a job, to get your benefits, you have to go to a government institution called "P√¥le Emploi". They will manage your rights based on familly status, owned property, previous position... a special councilor is assigned to you, he will study your case and determine a plan of action for you to get a job, depending on experience: same field, conversion trough training to acquire new skills, etc,... Every month, you have to check in, give reports, he will give you some info that might have come about on specific fields, or open job positions. Another branch of the same institution will check everything you do, verify the amount of job applications, call employers to have an idea of your behavior in an interview or an trial period, that kind of thing. You can also have one of those inspectors randomly shop up at your door to see if you are looking for a job, in which case you will have to whip out the paperwork in front of him. Those things are done daily, in the entire country.


I think there is also a difference in how we percieve work in France. It is not as much a survival necessity on the financial level as it is in the US (well, it is, but it isn't considered as such). We work less, because we value familly life and social interaction a lot, as well as personal growth and social contribution, and it is taught quite young. For instance, we don't have a military service, but a civic service. between the age of 16 and 25, you can participate in the institution of your choice to a task of social interest. It can be electrician for the city, caretaker for kids after school on school grounds, emergency services, elderly care in retirement homes.... Work here is the social network. Outside of it you enter family time. Human connection and social worth is found trough work or service.


As for the "mindset" I speak about, I will have to admit it is based on personal experience, not official studies. I have been myself homeless, jobless, homeless and jobless for some time (thank you 2008 crisis, altho it is better now, got a nice flat and a job). I have met many people in the same situation. It took me three months of having one meal three or four times a week to push the door of a charity. I was in the mindset that "I'm not about to take a meal that could be used by a mom with three kids or an elder, I'm young, able-bodied, I'll deal with it and find another way". Now that I'm more stable, I give some time to such a charity. I've seen poverty evolve and touch new categories of people these last years (mainly the elderly and college students). I remember a teenage girl who came to us. Her father lost his job, and had benefits, but they were too low to take care of four kids (her included) and pay for her school. So he did what he felt he had to do: he did not eat and fed his kids, sold his car to pay for the school and walked to look for a job. The girl came to ask if she could be the one on the file as recipient because her father's former coworker was one of the charity's helpers. He was too ashamed. A lot of elderly have the same reflex. I've had a lady in her 80's telling me (not knowing I was working there) that I could get the juice bottle we had just given her because "young folk have more need for vitamins than an old useless bat" (her words). Poverty is not often inherited here as it is in the US from what I gathered (trailer parks and such are an image we get a lot here from your country. I don't really know to what extent they are relevant). It is encountered trough a life mishap.


I have seen a lot of violence coming from the poorer classes of society, often desperate people lead by a few less morally inclined people, but also a majority of kindness and cooperation to survive. One of the most basic things among homeless people with dogs, for instance, is that they will feed their dog before themselves, for the simple reason that the dog is often the only friend they have. I think the biggest plight of poverty is solitude, isolation. Once we manage to solve that, things tend to take a better turn. For the last three years that I have been in that charity, I think I've encountered 5 or 6 people that were truly scum with no drive for anything but themselves (we serve 1M meals a year).


Also, the lgbt question piqued my interest because I come from a VERY christian background, but happen to be gay and now an atheist (let's just say I'm not exactly welcome in my parent's house anymore). I find strange the areas you cite as reasons for being against the topic. Apart from the nutjobs parading in leather on pride day that make a quite vocal (might I say way too loud) minority of the people in the lgbt situation (I call it situation rather than community. The majority of people with same sex attraction or trans identity never even try to include themselves in militant groups, or even communicate with them, contrary to what said groups would pretend to be, some sort of unified monolith representing everybody) are stable and quite average and usual people. Most of the time when there is an impact related to lgbt people on society, it is due to prejudice (not running the old suffering marathon, I despise it, but hear me out). Mental health issues related to that topic often arise when a person is discriminated or pressured by other people. As for children involved, many studies show the kids perform as well as any other kids, altho the sampling size is too small to be conclusive, which is to be expected when only 5% of the population as a whole are homosexuals, let alone parents. The most honest thing to say is "There is nothing to this day to bring definitive proof on them better or worse off". I don't want any kids, the only reason being social impact on them for having two dads. But that is more a choice I make because of society rather than personal inabillity. As for birth rates, well, that's a non-topic. I'm not about to turn straight anytime soon, be it legal or not to be gay, since it isn't a choice. And having sex just to further the line and give a nudge to demographics, mechanically, with no feelings involved, is not something that seems an option to me... The real reason the pushed me personnaly to be for same sex marriage in my country was a matter of financial equality. Married couples pay less taxes. Why should I pay more than my neighbours because I'm not married to a woman, and stuck with the interdiction to marry my partner? That was the train of tought.


Again, I want to thank you for the calm you display in a conversation, it is truly refreshing. I also apologise for any errors, english is not my primary language and I'm typing this at 5 am. Feel free to answer about what anything you want and exclude any topic, I'm not trying to start a debate of any sort, just seeking some outside perspective from polite people on what I guess is the "other side" of the political spectrum (another thing that seems strange as somebody foreign to the US. How did you manage to not kill each other both inside and outside the only two parties you have? We have at least 30 sitting in the Assembl√©e currently (equivalent to congress) and still nobody inside them agrees with each other).


Looking forward to your answer as well.

replies.author: @rouchenelvann
replies.text:
K. V.   

My apologies for the delay. I suffered the loss of a close friend yesterday. 

I‚Äôd first like to share my gratitude and appreciation for people like you (namely, those who put forth their time to help others, and who genuinely care about the passions of others.) I can understand why you hold the position that you do regarding the system and those who take advantage of it vs those who utilize it due to necessity. It is definitely different here in America. I don‚Äôt want to give off the illusion that everyone here is taking advantage of the system, because that would be a gross exaggeration, but there are many among us who have married the system for benefits and luxury. There‚Äôs only a reluctance among those of us who value work and would rather make our own way, but have fallen on hard times. 

Regarding the lgbt community, i do agree that there is a small sect of flamboyant individuals holding the bullhorn making their views seem like the position of the whole. I‚Äôm sorry that you‚Äôre not accepted because of your views and sexuality. I don‚Äôt think that we do anyone a service by rejecting them. It never addresses or resolves the underlying issues. It only compounds things further. But, if I may respond sincerely, I‚Äôd like to offer a few points to consider. To the point of the studies which state that kids in same sex families perform as well as other kids, I‚Äôve read a few studies that have drawn the same conclusion, but here‚Äôs my issue with the ones I‚Äôve seen. Firstly, they are written by homosexual activists who seem to already set out to merely prove their position, not necessarily to ascertain truth. There also seems to be many variables not taken into consideration with said studies. There is also an elephant in the room when leaning on such studies: if fatherless homes have devastating effects on children (and ultimately society at large) as well as motherless homes, then how can it be concluded that homes without such function just as well as homes with such? There‚Äôs an extensive body of research thoroughly detailing the effects of fatherless homes. There‚Äôs psychological literature, statistics, etc, which give us a clear picture of what happens when the biological father is absent from the home. And there are no sound studies (at least not in my opinion) which show that replacing one of the biological parents with someone else is just as good as having the biological mother and father in the home. There‚Äôs also an issue regarding step parents and frequency of abuse, the domestic violence aspect (especially among homosexual women. A recent study indicating that same sex relationships among women have a higher rate of domestic than both same sex make couples and heterosexual couples), mental health (which I don‚Äôt think comes as a result of pressure, but rather is exasperated by it.) Which brings me to a deeper point. 

I understand what you mean when you say that being gay/trans isn‚Äôt a choice. I agree. But here‚Äôs where we get into an issue that actually piggybacks off of what I just stated regarding fatherless homes. Dr Joseph Nicolosi has demonstrated with amazing efficiency that among males homosexuality is actually the result of child development and absent, passive, or overbearing fathers. This is why many feel that they were born gay. That‚Äôs a false position to hold, but it‚Äôs a result of them being that way since they could remember (going back to early stages of development.) Dr Nicolosi is the creator of reparative therapy, also known as reintergrative therapy (not to be confused with conversion therapy) and had a 100% conversion rate among males, further showing that one is not born gay, or trans, but rather that one who projected something that was missing onto the same sex in an unnatural way. Sorry for the oversimplification. I would really recommend looking him up. He has lectures on YouTube where he explains it in detail. 

I don‚Äôt think, considering what I‚Äôve laid out above, that it‚Äôs appropriate to assume that the only effects on society are merely that of prejudice. But I also don‚Äôt think that rejection or quarantine is the solution. Sadly people use religion as a battering ram, demolishing everything that they disagree with, and tearing down people in the process. I‚Äôm not here to condemn you. I think we could be very good friends, actually. But I digress. Hopefully I‚Äôve offered a point worthy of your consideration. I look forward to your response.

replies.author: @SmartGrowthBayCounty
replies.text:
‚Äã@rouchenelvann, I have been reading some of your comments here, I wanted to thank you for your calm and pro-social disposition, definitely unusual to see on youtube comments.

I want to address really quick your reference to a Doctor Joseph Nicolosi- I think you may have been misled by certain christian activists, speakers, and self-described therapists into believing the evidence supports the idea that homosexuality is unnatural or wrong. I know that isn't your exact words but based on the body of your previous comment I don't think it's inaccurate. One thing I would like to point to- you say that the pro-conversion therapy doctor "has demonstrated with amazing efficiency that among males homosexuality is actually the result of child development and absent, passive, or overbearing fathers.". Notice how broad that comment is. Based on that premise, my homosexuality could be the result of a father who was absent, OR it could be the result of a father who was TOO present! (overbearing). Pseudoscientists like Dr Nicolosi (sorry if this term bothers you but it is accurate in my experience) usually will refer to "studies" they have done, without mentioning that they lack peer review or double-blindness, which is crucial to conducting effective studies, ESPECIALLY if you are trying to answer big picture questions like "why are people gay".

One last thing, and I encourage your response if you feel like chatting over these sources- you also mention that Nicolosi has a "100% conversion rate". You should understand that this is a high-bordering-on-impossible success rate for any therapy. It sounds to me like magical thinking. Even medically sanctioned therapies for mental disorders like CBT do not sport a 100% success rate. It is unfortunate but frequently conartists will draw people in with magical thinking and unrealistic promises only to ruin their lives later down the line.

Once again I appreciate your candor and straightforwardness, and I hope you can appreciate mine. I don't mean to step on your toes but I have a lot of experience studying disinformation and cults... Just to give you a bit of background on myself. 

Best wishes,

Sleepysloth

P.S. So sorry to hear about the loss of your friend. I hope that you are able to find peace in these trying times- I hope you know we are all suffering a profound disruption in our lives, and you are not alone.

author: @Muslimah1987
text:
A lot of these anti-anti-SJW channels have been popping up in my feed lately. 

Admittedly, I did spend the last 3-4 years exploring the anti-SJW rabbit-hole (right up to Red Ice might I add), I did so more out of curiosity than conviction. Far too many folks however - especially young men - are really becoming enamoured by such ideas, especially when presented by those posing as the 'valiant defenders of Western Civilisation' and are buying straight into their message, without a second critical thought (suspiciously like the SJWs they love to hate...oh the irony).

While I must be grateful for the valuable lessons learned from Molyneux et al, the inevitable conclusion of their worldview - a toxic mess of racial supremacy and hyper-individualism - made it impossible to accept. Then there were the gaping loopholes in their arguments but you already know about those :P   

I think channels like yours are our best bet to save people. The clear-headed, thorough examination of the subject matter instead of increasingly hysterical polemics (which I now realise is to compensate for the lack of real substance) - will win over levelheaded people who simply wanted the most accurate picture of things rather than one saturated with labels from either SJWs or the other side of the same coin. 

As a Muslim, this video in particular was a welcome addition. 

Sincerely, thank you.

The crusades were good, you just need to stop being so BIASED. That‚Äôs the word. The truth is everything and everyone is biased, so we should stop arguing about the past in a political sense, and just accept its history, it‚Äôs nuanced. there were good and bad parts to both sides and to simply lean on one is disingenuous and foolish. replies.text:
@frankmcgovern5445 well this will take some time.


1st) I never called YouTube itself authoritarian. I said it was pushing people to the "far-left" which is authoritarian. And this is true, Tim Pool has shown many times how YouTube has a strong pull on the "right" and center towards the "left". Yes the majority of your recommendations are related to what you watch, but YouTube sprinkles the "left" all over. Meanwhile there is barely any pull on the "left" towards either the center or "right". This is just YouTube's bias, that doesn't make anyone a victim, especially since you still have to click on the videos yourself (unless you have autoplay on, but that's still a choice you make).


2nd) I have also never claimed the "right" can't be SJWs, in fact I am of the opinion that the "right" was the original SJWs. There was all that bullshit about "Dungeons & Dragons", the censorship of entertainment (especially rap & rock music, and video games), and the bullshit with homosexuals. Now the "left" has taken up the mantle of SJW. If you have to add a modifier to the word "justice" it ceases to be justice.


3rd) There's plenty of hate speech on YouTube that gets ignored. It's just an excuse that is applied when there's no real reason for deplatforming. Just like Patreon , kicking Sargon for saying "nigger" and yet there are plenty of people that make even more than him who are still on their platform, even after being brought to their attention. There's also the fact that private businesses have been treated like public spaces before (again Tim Pool covered this), heck even Twitter has that with not being allowed to kick Trump.
There is some leeway in libel laws that allow journalist to make accusations as if fact while claiming they are opinions later. Granted I don't think the laws need more power. Only 5 president's, including Trump, have won despite losing the popular vote.
Gerrymandering is pretty shit and used by both sides to try and eliminate the voice of their opponent. The electoral college though is necessary. Also if more people would actually get out and vote, we could get away from this pathetic two party system.
This claim is going to need some proof, funny how there's so much "right" wing murder that Jussie Smollett had to make up his hate crime, and the lies with the Covington Catholic kids. I will grant you that the "left" doesn't seem to have murdered anyone, but they are still assaulting people constantly.


4th) There's a big difference between regulation and banning. Also your misconstruing the "well-regulated" part,
"A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."
There is nothing in that that says the firearms are to be "well-regulated".


5th) Are you talking about this?
"The FAKE NEWS media (failing @nytimes, @NBCNews, @ABC, @CBS, @CNN) is not my enemy, it is the enemy of the American People!"
He called out  5 specific outlets. That is not the same as saying all free media is bad.
Are you honestly going to suggest that no free press could be lying? How is the media misportraying news in order to push a divisive agenda, not bad for us the people?
Already covered the libel stuff.
And here we have the perfect example of fake news. Tell me, how do you know these children are being permanently separated from their parents? How do you know that the people they crossed with where their parents? Oh that's right, you have no idea. You would prefer to leave these children with potential strangers who have kidnapped them (and statistically speaking most likely raped them if they're girls) because you care so much about these kids. Meanwhile ignoring all the actual US children stripped from their parents over nonsense.
There are people actually calling for the abolishment of our borders.


Bonus: since you whined about the border issue, where were you when Obama was doing the exact same thing? Hell some of the pictures they used to damn Trump, where from Obama's time.

Short answer: Partially
Long answer: There were a lot of incentives within the church, partially having the motivations to help an ally and put a stop to muslims invasions, not to forget their advances over Iberia also motivated a lot to hit them back,but under all the motivations the motivation of taking it for monetary gain was a big part to do so as well, just as the caliphate had invaded and kept the land before them
In summary, the intentions of the political game are to complex to try and look for right and wrong, even less in the old times where most were invading each other and they all to some extent supported practices seen as savage nowdays
The church was a big institution and the motivations of an individual or kings to go to war can  be many
And even if somebody is an absolutist who says only greed was part of the invasion to conquer and keep the land, then also the muslims doing the same,invading and keeping rule of the land with no other religious motivation behind is also "logical",but no their institutions were also complex and their motivations many,including politcal gain, even worse in their case, since not even defending anyone was part of the equation,also that does not change the fact of muslim agresivness (which also does not mean neither side were or could have been equally agressive hell the crudades sacked constantinople and kept invading asia minor)
But the truth is, its just humans being human conquering each other and always seeking politcal gain as a result of their actions,true,but that does not mean religious intentions to take land  (in both invasions of the holy land chirstian and muslim)were not in the mind of all leaders at the time or that none of the minor players and soldiers involved in the case of the crusades wanted to  make muslims advances stop,which it did for a while
And even if it was not defensive said muslim advances (just like any others)dont really allow them to have the moral authority over certain issues
Even if their intention was not to defend the byzantines it clearly had in mind to stop their advances towards europe to avoid another Spain, which it did as I said but was not successful
specifically all the way to vienna
Ps: I meant caliphates in plural I know there were more than one at the same time
Also no,they were quite succeful at least for a while of stoping muslim agression,which did not work long term and their ottoman succesor invaded all the way to Viena
The byzantine emperor literally asked the pope to invade the holy land to stop the muslims advances which it did ,true the pope in particular did not care that much about the empire (he put stratigic importance before religious liking with them) but many people in the church kings and soldiers did,plus the adjacent and obvious goal that even the pope saw of stopping the muslims regardless if he cared or not about the empire to avoid another muslims invasion of europe just as it happened in spain which it did for a while, and to try to ensure that goal,also invaded asia minor just as the muslims had done before
And yes a dick move that to assure their "compensation" they betrayed them but the invasion of asia minor was to try to put defennes on the hands of the church,because the byzantines sucked at defending from the muslims

replies.text:
gerbenvanessen the extent depends on the region. In the Baltic‚Äôs, undoubtedly. Less so in areas of the Roman Empire post-Constantine, given the empire was already long established the internal prostelysation was likely far less bloody than if it had been external via religious conquest, I.e. the Islamic conquests of the Levant, Persia, etc. 
Germany‚Äôs a mixed bag; some barbarian tribes like the Vandals and Visigoths converted over time of their own accord, but others like those in Saxony got hit hard by the Carolingians during the eastern expansion of Francia. Afterwards, conversions may‚Äôve been forced in local populations, but usually by rulers who had converted to Christianity willingly, like in Denmark, Poland and Bulgaria. Not really much better, but it was likely politically motivated equally as much as religiously motivated as a means to reinforce the divine right to rule.

Bit I liked: 
"They tell you in college Christians TOOK Jerusalem. Took BACK, they should say!" 
Right... so at what point did Christians control Jerusalem before 1099? If memory serves, it belonged to Jews, then the Fatimids took it in the 7th century, then the Seljuks conquered it (cue Crusade), then the Fatimids got it back one year before 1099... so when exactly did Christians have it in the first place? How'd they take it "back" unless they had it first?

replies.author: @cohorsevocata
replies.text: @travishimebaugh8381 Jewish rule over the region had been largely over by the second century A.D., having been crushed by the Romans in response to several Jewish revolts. You could argue that since the Byzantines inherited Jerusalem in the unraveling and division of the Roman Empire and they were mostly Christian from 400 A.D., it had indeed been "under Christian rule". It's rather reductive to refer to that period as such though, as Byzantine vs Frankish rule and Fatamid vs Abbasid rule etc. aren't fully the same. Claiming that the Latin Crusaders "retook" Jerusalem ignores that the Franks didn't really have a claim to the region prior to the region.

replies.author: @juanjoseph

@claudiu-mihaipuiu1221 


"Even Pope Urban condemned them for their deeds at the time"
There you go, you yourself made up a case for the Crusades not being like that.


" I think he meant why didn't the rest of Christianity rise up to protect Jerusalem when it was first taken over by Muslims, or anywhere in the aftermath of that?"


That is a very stupid, false, and laughable point.  I'll explain:


-The first Crusades were about defending Europe from the advancing muslims. You have the victory of Charles Martel, regarded as the first crusade, the Norman conquest of Sicily, the first battles for the Reconquista, the defence of Touluse, etc, centuries before the First Crusade to Outremer.
-War needs money. At the time of the muslim conquests, Europe was a developing economy. For centuries Europe had depended on eastern trade and grain to sustain itself. Like, remember why Ptolemaic Egypt, Anatolia, and the buffer Seleucids were so important to the Roman Republic and latter to the Roman Empire.
When the trade gateway to the East was broken, the european princes saw themselves almost completely empoverished and without a good food chain supply. This economic crisis is what led to what we understand as Feudalism.


So, to ask why european christians couldn't retaliate agaunst the muslim hordes at the start of the muslim conquests is.... pretty ignorant. It is like asking why can a mugged man ask for a cab.




"Also, it was done for politics. Save for perhaps Raymond of Toulouse, most of the major leaders of the Crusade were there more for political gain then any religious fervor they might've had. I mean, a few of them established Crusader states and dropped out of the Crusades completely."

Heck, you didn't even need a fully unified continent with how faith was viewed at the time, one call to arms and you'd have an army in no time, but at no point in time did anybody, king or pope care that much at the time about Jerusalem falling since it didn't affect them directly. replies.author: @PatternistSlave
replies.text:
Red Dundee Historical revisionism is neither bad, nor good intrinsically. In some instances it is necessary to achieve a more balanced picture of the past. Especially in areas where documented bias has existed in the Historical record.

Historical analysis that employs a specific disciplinary perspective to shed a different light on Historical events has its uses and its efficacy.

 Revisionism that purposefully distorts the Historical record to push a specific agenda is intellectual dishonesty of the highest order and the purview of hacks. It is a rejection of the basic tenets of the discipline and highly unethical.

My favorite professor called being a Historian, "learning to read between the lies." That is the Historian's responsibility. Even the lies we tell ourselves. We are all products of our own conditioning, and we all analyze the past through our own subjective worldview. 

It's the job of the Historian to recognize that, to fight to break our own conditioning, our own prejudices and preconceptions, and view the Historical record as objectively as we can manage. 

Our job to try to understand the conditioning and cultural realities of individuals in the past to attain a better understanding of their motivations and actions. To avoid anachronistic expectations of their behavior. 

No one is perfect. Shedding your personal biases and modern cultural viewpoint must always be a continuing work in progress.

But those who purposefully spread misinformation for their own purposes, and to promote their own socio-political worldview, need to fuck right off to their proper milieu of Alternative History Fantasy Fiction. Where they belong.

ILoveCoffee What is Europe then ? Where is the line between Europe and Asia? They both share the same continent, the same tectonic plate for geography's sake. By your logic I should say "Eurasia" in the name of silk road. Eurasia  pretty much had contact. They share so much together. 



What will affect "Asia" will affect "Europe" in one way or another. Remember how the Roman Byzanthium stole silk making from China and become more rich ? Remember How the Abbassids Stole Paper making from China, start their golden age and introduce paper in Europe ? Paper, Silk and Gun powder are chinese inventions so why not studying China and Europe at the same time ?  Our numeral system (the 1 to 10) was invent in India (South Asia) and introduce by arabs (Middle east). Why not studying South Asia and Middle East then ?


As for the history of China, Well... China is very VERY old. They had so much Civil wars (An Lushan rebellion, 3 kingdoms etc.) It's normal someone will specialize in a certain period or place in China without studying China entirely.



Europe's history  is aleready large so dividing east and west is pretty logical. Like     Rasengan     said : "People specialise in certain strands of History". What I am saying is history is large. Study your part and I'll study mine so we can piece this together.

replies.author: @saladcaesar7716
replies.text:
ILoveCoffee I get what do you mean in this paragraph "no east nor west Europe". However I don't het why would you say earlier : "There is no such thing as eastern European history. There is just European history.". I know many European civilisations had contacts but not to a point of being "one Europe". I know for Roman empire but They barely met the Scandinavians.


I agree for abolishing cold war terms like "West or East Europe". But I disagree for the term "European History". Because then again Where is the line between Europe and Asia. I heard many people saying Russia is European. I know for Byzanthium cultural influence on the Slavs but when I look at the map, Russia is pretty much Asian. As for turkey Geographicaly it's consider European under Byzanthium but since the Ottoman, People call ex-Anatolia Middle-East even though Turks are from Central Asia. 



When I look at the map beyond history and culture, I don't see the line between Europe and Asia.

replies.author: @saladcaesar7716
replies.text: ILoveCoffee By Slavs being influenced by Byzanthium, I was reffering to orthodoxy and architecture. Some Russian architectures reminds me a lot of Byzanthium. I understand what do you mean by European history but I still don't get where is the limit to Europe. Especially when it comes to the Rus. Modern Russians are related to medieval Rus. BUT They were invaded (but not entirely) by Mongols who are Asian nomads. So Rus shared a bit of asian then ? Where is the border of Europe ? I know many European coutries share culture and history. But what are the requirements to be European? Is Armenia European because they are christian and recieve Byzanthium influence?

replies.author: @chuckthedragon5332
replies.text: Where Bohemians Christians?

replies.author: @saladcaesar7716
replies.text:
ILoveCoffee Interesting point of view. But when peole say "European history" I ask wich one at wich period? The conversation starts with a "there is no east Europe history just Europe history" I disagree because history is vast Some people should specialize in one perticular branch. Of course "East Europe" is an oversimplifyed umbrella term to include countries in the "east" side: polland, Greece, Bellarus etc.


Europe was not always interconnected as today. It always depends on what period, what situation, what context etc. By not always interconnected I mean:  Roman empire didn't contact the Scandinavians on a daily baisis. Maybe they traded but it's not your local grocery store. Maybe they once fought but it's not your annoying neighbor. That's why the term "European history" doesn't always work. At some periods, some European civilisations didn't even saw each other or they were aware of each others existence but It stops there.

replies.author: @saladcaesar7716
replies.text: ILoveCoffee I see. So you wanna abolish the term "east west Europe" and remplace it with more specific terms like balkan or scandivian history because east and west are not regions.

replies.author: @prierepanda2186
replies.text:
ILoveCoffee Europe is not closed off in any way. People create subdivision of things for the sake of simplicity all the time. Eastern Europe is one, and, I can tell you has an historian, it's widely used amongst scholar talking about medieval to contemporary history.
It's a useful term that describe something pretty easely understandable.

The argument you give to refuse this distinction could be used against any kind of geographical distinction in history.

replies.author: @herec0mestheCh33f
replies.text: history is big yo. Grouping it into smaller groups helps. This isn't like national idpol, which i would gladly delete given all the harm it brings.
